When you ask the patient to slowly lower his right arm to his side when he holds it overhead, you note that he suddenly drops his arm and appears to be in pain. The patient's strength is 1/5 for abduction of the right arm. Which of the following is most likely injured in this patient?
Prediction:
The most likely injured muscle in this patient is the supraspinatus (Option A). The patient's history of sudden onset of pain and weakness in the right shoulder after lifting heavy objects, coupled with the physical exam findings of weakness in abduction (lifting the arm away from the body) and the drop-arm sign (inability to lower the arm slowly from a raised position due to pain) are indicative of a supraspinatus injury or tear. This muscle is part of the rotator cuff and is particularly important for abduction of the arm.

The other options (B, C, D, and E) are also muscles that can be involved in shoulder injuries, but the clinical presentation and exam findings are most consistent with a supraspinatus injury. The infraspinatus and teres minor are involved in external rotation of the shoulder, the subscapularis in internal rotation, and the deltoid in abduction, but the specific drop-arm sign and the patient's description of pain and weakness when lifting are more indicative of a supraspinatus issue.

Question: A 9-year-old male visited his primary care physician for a check-up three months after a throat infection. Upon examination, the patient exhibits painless subcutaneous nodules on the back of the wrist, the outside elbow, and the front of the knees, as well as inflammation in the joints of the lower extremities. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to also be present in this patient?
Prediction: The presence of subcutaneous nodules and joint inflammation in a child following a throat infection suggests a diagnosis of rheumatic fever. Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that can develop after a group A streptococcal infection, such as strep throat or scarlet fever. It can affect the heart, joints, skin, and brain. Among the options given, chorea (Option C) is the most likely additional symptom to be present in this patient. Chorea, also known as Sydenham's chorea, is characterized by involuntary movements and is a complication of rheumatic fever affecting the brain. It is not as directly associated with the other options listed, which are more commonly related to other conditions or diseases.

Question: A 29-year-old man diagnosed with schizophrenia 4 years ago presents for follow-up to discuss his medication. The patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia 4 years ago and has since tried several antipsychotic medications, none of which have been able to treat his negative symptoms. He has changed to clozapine 2 weeks ago and says that he does feel better. His physical exam is unremarkable, and he is responding appropriately to questioning. If this patient’s current medication is to be continued, which of the following laboratory tests should be ordered at this time?
Prediction: The correct answer is D. Complete blood count. Clozapine can cause agranulocytosis, a potentially life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, so regular complete blood counts are necessary to monitor for this side effect. Typically, weekly complete blood counts are done for the first 6 months of treatment, and then every 2-4 weeks thereafter.

Question: A 32-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of weight loss, night sweats, and productive cough. Auscultation of the lungs shows coarse crackles at the right upper posterior field. An x-ray of the chest shows an opacity in the right upper lobe. Sputum analysis shows acid-fast bacilli. A small amount of tuberculin fluid is injected into the subcutaneous tissue on the left forearm. Examination of the injected area 48 hours later shows no induration or erythema. Impairment of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of the negative tuberculin skin test seen in this patient?
Prediction: The most likely cause of the negative tuberculin skin test seen in this patient is an impairment of the interaction of B7 and CD28 ligands (Option B). The tuberculin skin test is a type of delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) reaction that depends on cell-mediated immunity. In patients with HIV, the CD4+ T cells, which are essential for this type of immune response, are depleted. The interaction between B7 on antigen-presenting cells and CD28 on T cells is critical for T cell activation and the subsequent immune response to the tuberculin antigen. Impairment of this interaction due to HIV-induced immunodeficiency can result in a negative tuberculin skin test, even in the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

Question: A 7-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency room after losing consciousness 30 mins ago at home. The patient’s mother says that he has had a “running nose” for the past few days However, he did not receive any treatment for it, and his condition rapidly worsened today. He does not have any significant past medical history. His vaccination records are up to date. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 22/min. On physical examination, the patient is unresponsive. There is a petechial rash present on his chest, and he has some neck rigidity. Empiric intravenous antibiotics are started, and a lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s low blood pressure?
Prediction: The most likely cause of this patient’s low blood pressure, given the symptoms and signs described, is septic shock. The patient's symptoms of a running nose that rapidly worsened, high fever, low blood pressure, tachycardia (rapid heart rate), and the presence of a petechial rash and neck rigidity suggest a severe systemic infection. The petechial rash and neck rigidity are particularly concerning for meningococcal sepsis, which can lead to septic shock. None of the options provided (A. Miliary tuberculosis, B. Human immunodeficiency virus infection, C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, D. Adrenocortical insufficiency, E. Pheochromocytoma) are as likely to cause the constellation of symptoms and signs as septic shock. However, the specific cause of the septic shock would need to be determined by further investigation, such as blood cultures and the results of the lumbar puncture.

Question: A chronic opioid abuser undergoes emergency surgery. Following the operation, the man is started on a patient controlled analgesia (PCA) thought to be dosed adequately to control his pain in the face of his opioid tolerance. He reports intense pain 6 hours after the conclusion of the surgery. Which agent could have been given intraoperatively to reduce this patient's risk of developing postoperative hyperalgesia?
Prediction:
A. Ketamine

Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that has been shown to have a role in the prevention of postoperative hyperalgesia. It works by blocking NMDA receptors, which are involved in the development of central sensitization and opioid tolerance. By preventing the activation of these receptors during surgery, ketamine can help reduce the risk of developing postoperative hyperalgesia, especially in patients with a history of chronic opioid use.

Question: A 3550-g (7.8-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old, gravida 1, para 1 woman (Rh+). Within the first 24 hours after birth, the newborn develops fever and a yellow discoloration of skin and sclerae. Examination shows loss of flexion in the extremities, splenomegaly, and cyanosis. Laboratory studies show decreased haptoglobin levels and increased LDH levels. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
Prediction:
The newborn's symptoms of fever, yellow discoloration of skin and sclerae (jaundice), loss of flexion in the extremities, splenomegaly, and cyanosis, along with laboratory findings of decreased haptoglobin levels and increased LDH levels, are indicative of hemolysis. The presence of maternal antibodies against the rhesus D antigen (Option B) is the most likely cause of this condition, known as Hemolytic Disease of the Newborn (HDN) or Hemolytic Disease of the Fetus and Newborn (HDFN).

In this scenario, the mother is Rh+, but the newborn could have inherited the RhD antigen from the father, making the newborn Rh+. During delivery, fetal red blood cells (RBCs) can enter the maternal circulation. If the mother is Rh- and the fetus is Rh+, the mother's immune system may produce IgG antibodies against the RhD antigen on the fetal RBCs. These antibodies can cross the placenta and attack the fetal RBCs, leading to hemolysis and the symptoms described.

The other options do not fit the clinical presentation as well:

A. Decrease in the reduced form of glutathione is associated with conditions like G6PD deficiency, which can cause hemolysis but is not specifically related to the Rh incompatibility scenario described.

C. Point mutation in β-globin is associated with conditions like sickle cell anemia or β-thalassemia, which also cause hemolytic anemia but do not involve maternal antibodies.

D. Deficiency of ATP is not a known cause of hemolytic anemia in newborns.

E. Osmotically fragile erythrocytes can be a feature of hereditary spherocytosis, which can cause hemolytic anemia but is not related to maternal antibodies and Rh incompatibility.

Question: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion, anxiety, sweating, and episodes of vomiting. She is accompanied by her sister who says that her symptoms developed acutely and is unsure about what caused it. She is currently on methimazole, which she last took approximately 1 week ago. Approximately 5 days ago she developed an upper respiratory infection managed with bed rest and ibuprofen. Her temperature is 105°F (40.6°C), blood pressure is 95/68 mmHg, pulse is 145/min, and respirations are 23/min. On physical examination, the patient has altered mentation and is agitated and diaphoretic. The patient also has a goiter, exophthalmos, warm skin, and a hand tremor. She is started on intravenous fluids. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
Prediction:
The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis, specifically thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is a medical emergency characterized by high fever, tachycardia, agitation, sweating, vomiting, and other symptoms due to extremely high levels of thyroid hormones. The presence of a goiter and exophthalmos also suggest a history of hyperthyroidism, likely due to Graves' disease.

The best treatment option for this patient is E. Propranolol. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can help to control the symptoms of thyroid storm by blocking the effects of thyroid hormones on the heart and other organs. It can help to reduce tachycardia, tremor, anxiety, and other symptoms. In addition to propranolol, other treatments may be necessary, such as antithyroid medications, iodine, and corticosteroids, depending on the severity of the storm and the underlying cause of hyperthyroidism.

Options A, B, C, and D are not appropriate for the treatment of thyroid storm. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection. Carotid massage is not relevant to the treatment of thyroid storm. Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine that can be used to control anxiety and agitation but does not address the underlying cause of thyroid storm. Epinephrine is a potent stimulant that could exacerbate the symptoms of thyroid storm.

Question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he was vomiting and seemed abnormally sleepy at home. On presentation, he is found to be confused and very lethargic. His parents said that he has had a fever and cough for several days prior to presentation and was given an over the counter medication. Physical exam of this patient reveals mild hepatomegaly and dry mucous membranes. Which of the following effects would the drug most likely also have on the nephron?
Prediction:
The symptoms described (vomiting, confusion, lethargy, fever, cough, hepatomegaly, and dry mucous membranes) suggest that the patient may have taken an overdose of an over-the-counter medication, possibly acetaminophen (paracetamol), which is known to cause hepatotoxicity. Acetaminophen overdose can also lead to renal impairment, but its direct effect on the nephron is not primarily through altering the tone of the afferent and efferent arterioles.

However, if we are to consider the effects of the medication on the nephron based on the options provided, we can look at the general effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which are commonly used for fever and cough and can affect renal blood flow.

NSAIDs can cause constriction of the afferent arteriole due to their inhibitory effect on prostaglandin synthesis. Prostaglandins are vasodilators and play a crucial role in maintaining renal blood flow, particularly in the afferent arterioles. By inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, NSAIDs can lead to a reduction in renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR). However, NSAIDs typically do not have a significant effect on the efferent arteriole.

Therefore, the most likely answer based on the options provided and the potential effects of NSAIDs on the nephron would be:

B. Constriction of afferent arteriole and no effect on efferent arteriole

It is important to note that the specific medication taken by the patient is not mentioned, and the effects described can vary depending on the exact medication. Acetaminophen itself does not typically cause significant renal effects at therapeutic doses but can cause renal tubular damage at toxic doses, primarily through metabolic byproducts rather than direct vasoactive effects on the afferent and efferent arterioles.

Question: A 54-year-old woman presents with sudden onset, mild vaginal bleeding for the past day. She says she is postmenopausal, and her last menstrual period was 5 years ago. A detailed workup is performed, and several premalignant lesions are found in her uterus. The patient agrees to a hysterectomy. The surgical team decides to use an anesthesia protocol consisting of nitrous oxide, desflurane, and atracurium. Which of the following best describes the role of atracurium in this patient’s anesthesia?
Prediction:
D. It competes with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Its mechanism of action involves competing with acetylcholine for binding sites at the neuromuscular junction, which results in muscle relaxation. This is particularly useful during surgery to facilitate intubation and to maintain a relaxed surgical field.

Question: A 22-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of swelling in her face, hands, and neck with occasional abdominal pain. The symptoms usually resolve in 2 to 3 days. She has had these swelling events her whole life; however, they have become more debilitating recently. Last week she had an event that restricted her ability to eat and swallow.  Past medical history is noncontributory. Her father is alive and well with no significant medical history. Her mother and her maternal aunt have a similar condition. Today, her physical exam is within normal limits. She brought a picture of her swollen hand as seen in the picture. The treating physician has a strong suspicion of an inherited disorder. C1-inhibitor levels are ordered and found to be extremely low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
Prediction: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is E. Hereditary angioedema. Hereditary angioedema is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of swelling in various parts of the body, including the face, hands, and neck, and can also cause abdominal pain. The fact that the patient's mother and maternal aunt have a similar condition suggests a genetic component, and the low C1-inhibitor levels are consistent with this diagnosis. Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor, a protein that regulates the complement system and prevents excessive inflammation and swelling.

Question: A 24-year-old woman gravida 2, para 1 at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prediction:
The most appropriate next step in management for this patient is option A, an oral glucose challenge test. This test is typically performed between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation to screen for gestational diabetes, which is a common condition that can develop during pregnancy. The oral glucose challenge test involves drinking a glucose solution and then having blood glucose levels checked one hour later. If the blood glucose level is elevated, a more comprehensive glucose tolerance test may be recommended to confirm a diagnosis of gestational diabetes.

Options B, C, D, and E are also important aspects of prenatal care, but they are not the most appropriate next step at this point in the pregnancy for this patient. Cardiotocography (option B) is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions, but it is not typically performed as a routine screening test at this gestational age. Rh antibody testing (option C) is important for Rh-negative women, but this patient's blood type is B positive, so she is not at risk for Rh incompatibility. Swab for GBS culture (option D) is typically performed between 35 and 37 weeks of gestation to screen for group B streptococcus, which can cause serious infections in newborns. Tdap vaccination (option E) is recommended during each pregnancy, ideally between 27 and 36 weeks of gestation, to protect the mother and baby from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. However, since this patient is only 24 weeks pregnant, it is not yet the optimal time for this vaccination.

Question: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis that were preceded by 4 days of myalgia and a low-grade fever. He is currently visiting the United States as a tourist from Turkey, where he works at a factory that processes sheep wool and hide. An x-ray of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. A sputum culture grows gram-positive rods in gray colonies that have irregular margins with wavy projections on microscopy. Which of the following virulence factors of the causal organism increased its survival in host tissue?
Prediction:
The causal organism in this scenario is most likely Bacillus anthracis, which causes anthrax. The symptoms described, along with the occupation and travel history, are consistent with inhalational anthrax. The x-ray finding of a widened mediastinum is also characteristic of this condition.

Among the options provided, the virulence factor that increases the survival of Bacillus anthracis in host tissue is:

A. Glutamate capsule

Bacillus anthracis has a polysaccharide capsule made of poly-D-glutamic acid, not glutamate, but the closest option is (A). This capsule helps the bacteria resist phagocytosis by host immune cells, allowing the bacteria to survive and proliferate in the host's tissues. The other options listed are not associated with the virulence of Bacillus anthracis:

B. Toxin B is part of the binary toxin produced by Clostridium difficile, not Bacillus anthracis.
C. Protein A is a surface protein of Staphylococcus aureus, not Bacillus anthracis.
D. IgA protease is produced by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis, not Bacillus anthracis.
E. Sulfatides are not a known virulence factor for any of the mentioned bacteria. Sulfatides are lipids found in myelin and some bacteria, but they are not specifically associated with the virulence of Bacillus anthracis.

Question: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for active labor. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and a vacuum-assisted delivery is performed. Postpartum examination shows a third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?
Prediction: The most likely complication after a third-degree laceration extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position is C. Fecal incontinence. Third-degree lacerations involve the anal sphincter muscles, and if not repaired properly, can lead to issues with fecal continence.

Question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. He reports a slow and steady weight gain of 6 pounds over the past 6 months, despite attempts to control his diet and increase his level of exercise. His medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. On exam, his vital signs are stable. He is obese (BMI 32), and his waist circumference is 43 inches. His physician is concerned about an abnormal fasting blood glucose and dyslipidemia. On further work-up with oral glucose tolerance test, the patient is diagnosed with diabetes. Which of the following associations is consistent with this patient’s most likely form of diabetes?
Prediction:
The patient's presentation is most consistent with Type 2 diabetes, which is associated with obesity and insulin resistance. Among the options given, none directly describe Type 2 diabetes, but we can eliminate options that are more closely associated with Type 1 diabetes. Type 1 diabetes is characterized by auto-antibodies against pancreatic islet cell antigens (Option D) and pancreatic islet cell leukocyte infiltration (Option C). It is also not strongly associated with HLA class II gene makeup (Option A) as much as with HLA class I and other genetic factors. Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition (Option B) is a feature of some forms of diabetes, but it is not a defining characteristic of Type 2 diabetes. Given the patient's obesity and metabolic abnormalities, the correct answer is:

E. Unrelated to his abdominal obesity

However, this option is not entirely accurate as abdominal obesity is a significant risk factor for Type 2 diabetes. The best answer, given the options, would be to recognize that the patient's diabetes is indeed related to his abdominal obesity, but since that option is not available, the closest answer is E, which by process of elimination is the only option not directly associated with Type 1 diabetes.

Question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the right outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Prediction: The most likely diagnosis based on the given information is B. Phyllodes tumor. This is because the biopsy shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia, which is characteristic of phyllodes tumors. These tumors are typically multinodular, can grow rapidly, and are often larger than 5 cm. They are usually found in women in their 40s and 50s and can be benign, borderline, or malignant. The other options do not fit the description of the mass as well as phyllodes tumor does.

Question: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with dysphagia and halitosis. If this patient is also found to have cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction, which of the following is the most likely cause of his presenting symptoms?
Prediction:
The most likely cause of the patient's presenting symptoms, including dysphagia, halitosis, and cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction, is:

E. Zenker's diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum is a condition where a pouch forms in the posterior wall of the pharynx, typically at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. This can lead to dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) due to the pouch obstructing the esophagus and halitosis (bad breath) due to food particles getting trapped in the pouch. The cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction can also contribute to the symptoms by impairing the normal swallowing mechanism.

Question:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he has not been able to walk since waking up that morning. His mother said that when he tried to get out of bed that he was unable to stand without support. He also complained of prickling in his hands and feet. Three weeks ago, he had a fever, dry cough, and a sore throat. The fever and sore throat subsided a week after they began, but the cough is persisting. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is severe weakness in both lower extremities and mild sensory loss of the hands and feet. Knee and ankle jerk reflexes are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL
Leukocyte count 6000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 64%
Eosinophils 2%
Lymphocytes 26%
Monocytes 7%
Platelet count 160,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 27 mm/h
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.9 mEq/L
HCO3- 26 mEq/L
Ca2+ 9.7 mg/dL
Creatine kinase 93 U/L
A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 2/mm3, a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 91 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?"
Prediction:
The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a rapidly progressive, autoimmune-mediated polyneuropathy. The patient's history of a preceding respiratory illness, the acute onset of symmetric limb weakness, the absence of deep tendon reflexes, and the characteristic cerebrospinal fluid findings of albuminocytological dissociation (normal cell count with elevated protein) are all indicative of GBS.

The most appropriate next step in treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome is:

A. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

IVIG is one of the standard treatments for GBS, along with plasma exchange. It works by modulating the immune response and can help to halt the progression of the disease and improve recovery. Prednisone (Option B) is not typically used in the acute phase of GBS. Botulism antitoxin (Option C) is not indicated as there is no evidence of botulism in the clinical presentation. Intravenous acyclovir (Option D) is used for viral infections, particularly herpes simplex virus, which is not suggested in this case. Gabapentin (Option E) is used for neuropathic pain and would not be the initial treatment of choice for GBS.

Question: A 27-year-old male presents to the psychiatrist requesting help with his compulsions as they are interfering with his life. He explains that he has this fear that something terrible will happen to his house if he does not check every appliance, outlet, window and door lock, faucet, and light fixture before he leaves. He states that he must check everything 7 times in a specific order and if he goes out of order he must start from the beginning and perform it all over. He has recently been fired from his job because he is always late and lost his fiancee as she could not deal with his habits anymore. The physician explained that cognitive-behavioral therapy may be of assistance and also prescribed clomipramine. Which of the following is the mechanism of reaction of clomipramine?
Prediction:
The mechanism of action of clomipramine is that it blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin

Clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that primarily functions by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, thus increasing the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft. This can help alleviate symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and other anxiety disorders.

Question: A 35-year-old Caucasian female presents to the hospital alarmed by her recent truncal weight gain, facial hair growth, and thinning skin. During the physical exam, the physician finds that the patient is hypertensive. Serum analysis reveals hyperglycemia. The physician suspects a pituitary adenoma. Which dexamethasone test result would help confirm the physician's suspicions?
Prediction:
The dexamethasone suppression test is used to help diagnose Cushing's syndrome and determine its cause. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms consistent with Cushing's syndrome, which can be caused by a pituitary adenoma leading to excess ACTH production. The test involves administering dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, and measuring the response of the pituitary gland by observing changes in ACTH levels.

For a pituitary source of Cushing's syndrome, the expected response to the dexamethasone suppression test is as follows:

- Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test: ACTH levels do not suppress, indicating that the pituitary gland is not responding to the negative feedback of high cortisol levels, which is typical in Cushing's disease due to a pituitary adenoma.
- High-dose dexamethasone suppression test: ACTH levels do suppress, indicating that the pituitary tumor is sensitive to high doses of dexamethasone, which is a characteristic of Cushing's disease.

Therefore, the answer that would help confirm the physician's suspicions of a pituitary adenoma is:

E. Low-dose, no change in ACTH; high-dose, decreased ACTH

Question: A 24-year-old man with chronic back pain comes to the physician to establish care after moving to Florida. He complains of anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea for three days. He denies smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs. He appears restless. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection. His abdominal exam shows diffuse mild tenderness. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,000/mm, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3; serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
Prediction:
The patient's symptoms of anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection, along with his denial of smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs, suggest a withdrawal syndrome. The absence of rebound tenderness or guarding and normal laboratory results further support this diagnosis rather than an acute surgical abdomen.

Given the context of chronic back pain and the symptoms of withdrawal, the most likely scenario is opioid withdrawal. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for managing opioid withdrawal is methadone (Option C), which is a long-acting opioid agonist used for detoxification and maintenance treatment in opioid dependence. Methadone can help alleviate withdrawal symptoms and cravings, allowing the patient to stabilize and potentially transition to a non-opioid treatment for his back pain.

Options A (Lorazepam), B (Naltrexone), D (Morphine), and E (Naloxone) are not the first-line treatments for opioid withdrawal. Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used for anxiety and seizures but is not typically used for opioid withdrawal. Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used for the prevention of relapse in opioid-dependent patients after detoxification, but it is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms. Morphine is an opioid agonist that could potentially alleviate withdrawal symptoms but would not be an appropriate long-term solution for managing opioid withdrawal. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used for reversing acute opioid overdose but is not suitable for managing withdrawal symptoms.

Question: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10.1-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Prediction:
The most likely diagnosis for the 53-year-old man with the symptoms described is E. Lambert-Eaton syndrome. This diagnosis is supported by several key features in the patient's history and examination findings:

1. Progressive difficulty walking up stairs, which is a symptom of muscle weakness.
2. The observation that climbing stairs is easier after exercise, which is a characteristic feature of Lambert-Eaton syndrome known as "paradoxical improvement with exercise."
3. Weight loss over the past 6 months, which can be associated with the underlying malignancy that often accompanies Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
4. A history of smoking, which is a risk factor for the development of certain malignancies, such as small cell lung cancer, which is often associated with Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
5. Muscle strength initially 3/5 but increasing to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping, which is consistent with the electrophysiological pattern seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
6. A 1+ Achilles reflex, which is diminished but not absent, as would be expected in other conditions that affect the peripheral nerves.

The other options can be ruled out based on the following:

A. Polymyalgia rheumatica typically presents with pain and stiffness in the neck, shoulders, and hips but does not usually involve muscle weakness or the paradoxical improvement with exercise seen in this patient.

B. Myasthenia gravis can cause muscle weakness, but it does not typically present with the paradoxical improvement with exercise that is characteristic of Lambert-Eaton syndrome. Instead, symptoms tend to worsen with sustained activity.

C. Dermatomyositis can cause muscle weakness and weight loss, but it is typically associated with skin rashes and inflammation, which are not mentioned in this case.

D. Hypothyroidism can cause muscle weakness and weight gain, not weight loss. It also does not present with the paradoxical improvement with exercise seen in this patient.

Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is E. Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

Question: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice. CT demonstrates a mass in the head of the pancreas, and biopsy is planned for the following day. The patient's daughter approaches you outside the room to request that the results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient. She asks that the results instead be shared with her and her brother, who is the patient's documented health care proxy. She explains that she and her brother have discussed the situation and decided that it is best to not inform the patient that she has cancer. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided biopsy the next morning confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the best response to the patient's daughter's request?
Prediction: The best response to the patient's daughter's request is E. Tell the patient's daughter that the patient must be informed of the diagnosis. This is because the patient has a right to know her own medical condition, which is a fundamental principle of patient autonomy in medical ethics. However, it is important to handle this situation with sensitivity and to involve the family in a discussion about how and when to inform the patient, taking into account her emotional and psychological well-being. An ethics consult (option D) could also be helpful in navigating this complex situation, but the primary responsibility lies with the healthcare provider to ensure that the patient is informed about her diagnosis.

Question:
A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue. He has been seen in the emergency room 5 times in the past 2 years for acute alcohol intoxication. His past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus and gout. He takes metformin, glyburide, and allopurinol. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 16/min. He is in no acute distress. A positive fluid wave is noted. The dorsal surface of the tongue is depapillated, and there are erythematous swollen patches at the oral commissures. A complete blood count and iron studies are reported below:

Hemoglobin: 12.1 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Leukocyte count: 6,000/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 170,000/mm^3

Mean corpuscular volume: 70 um^3
Iron: 250 ug/dL
Ferritin: 300 ng/mL
Total iron binding capacity: 200 mcg/dL^3

Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
Prediction:
The patient's mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is 70 um^3, which is below the normal range (80-100 um^3), indicating microcytosis. The low MCV, along with the presence of diabetes and a history of alcohol abuse, suggests that the patient may have microcytic anemia, which is often associated with iron deficiency or chronic disease anemia. However, the iron studies show that the patient's serum iron, ferritin, and total iron binding capacity (TIBC) are all within or above the normal range, suggesting that iron deficiency is unlikely.

Given the patient's history of alcohol abuse, the most likely finding would be related to alcohol-induced anemia. Chronic alcohol abuse can lead to a variety of hematological abnormalities, including microcytic anemia due to nutritional deficiencies (e.g., folate, B12, iron), direct toxic effects of alcohol on the bone marrow, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's erythrocytes are likely to be hypochromatic, which means they have a decreased amount of hemoglobin relative to their size (Option D). This is a characteristic feature of microcytic anemia and would be consistent with the patient's low MCV.

The other options are less likely:
A. Erythroblasts with mitochondrial iron deposits would be seen in sideroblastic anemia, which is not suggested by the patient's iron studies.
B. Erythrocytes lacking central pallor would be seen in macrocytic anemia, which is not consistent with the patient's microcytic anemia.
C. Erythrocytes with a ring of relative pallor would be seen in normocytic anemia, which is not consistent with the patient's microcytic anemia.
E. Inclusions of denatured hemoglobin would be seen in conditions like sickle cell anemia or thalassemia, which are not suggested by the patient's history or laboratory results.

Question: A 75-year-old man becomes pulseless in the cardiac intensive care unit 48 hours after admission for ST-elevation myocardial infarction. His blood pressure is 50/20 mm Hg. The ECG monitor shows a tachycardic irregular rhythm with erratic undulations, but no discernible P waves or QRS complexes. During immediate advanced cardiac life support, two attempts at defibrillation are made, after which the patient is given 1 mg of IV epinephrine. After another attempt at defibrillation, the patient remains pulseless and his blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. The ECG monitor shows no changes. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prediction: The patient's description and ECG findings are consistent with ventricular fibrillation (VF), a chaotic, non-perfusing rhythm that requires immediate intervention. The initial management for VF includes CPR, defibrillation, and administration of epinephrine, which has already been performed. After two unsuccessful defibrillation attempts and epinephrine administration, the next step in management according to ACLS guidelines is to administer amiodarone. Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that can help to stabilize the heart's electrical activity and improve the chances of successful defibrillation. Therefore, the correct answer is B. Amiodarone.

Question: A 65-year-old man presents with left-sided numbness, diplopia, and blurring of vision. The diplopia is more prominent on his left-side lateral gaze. He denies having fever, headache, ocular pain, lacrimation, changes in color vision, or limb weakness. He has a past medical history of type-2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and ischemic heart disease. In addition, he had an ischemic stroke 9 years ago, from which he recovered completely with physiotherapy and rehabilitation. He has a history of a 56-pack-year cigarette smoking habit. His medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, glimepiride, metformin, metoprolol, and ramipril. The mental status examination is unremarkable. His muscle strength is normal in all 4 limbs. His sensations are decreased on his left side, including his face. The examination of extraocular movements is shown in the image. A lesion in which of the following locations explains the findings during eye examination?
Prediction:
The symptoms described, including left-sided numbness, diplopia, and blurring of vision, particularly with the diplopia being more prominent on left-side lateral gaze, suggest a lesion affecting the lateral gaze of the left eye. The examination of extraocular movements is not provided in the question, but assuming it is consistent with the symptoms described, the most likely location of the lesion is the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The MLF is a critical pathway for coordinating conjugate eye movements and is involved in the coordination of lateral gaze. A lesion in the MLF can result in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which is characterized by a failure of the adduction of one eye and nystagmus of the abducting eye when attempting to look to the side of the lesion. Given the patient's symptoms of diplopia that is worse on left-side lateral gaze, this is consistent with a right-sided MLF lesion, affecting the left eye's ability to adduct (move medially).

Therefore, the correct answer is:

E. Medial longitudinal fasciculus

Question: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. His respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?
Prediction:
The symptoms described in the patient, including poor feeding, irritability, noisy breathing, sunken fontanelles, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump, suggest a systemic infection, possibly sepsis, which can be common in neonates who did not receive prenatal care. However, the options provided seem to be more specific to neurological disorders. Given the context, none of the options directly correlate with the symptoms described. However, if we must choose the closest one to a potential neurological issue that could be secondary to the described condition, it would be:

E. Destruction of anterior horn cells

This is because destruction of anterior horn cells is associated with motor neuron diseases such as spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), which can present with muscle weakness and poor feeding in neonates. However, it's important to note that the primary issue in this case is likely a systemic infection, and the neurological symptoms could be secondary to that. The erythema around the umbilical cord stump suggests a possible umbilical infection, which is a common source of sepsis in neonates.

Question: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand. The stiffness is worse at the end of the day. She recently retired after working for 28 years as a typist at a data entry firm. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the first metacarpophalangeal joint and the distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender nodules are palpated over the 2nd and 4th distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. An x-ray of her right hand shows narrowing of the interphalangeal joint spaces with subchondral sclerosis and osteophytes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
Prediction: The most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition is E. Degenerative disease of the joints. The symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with osteoarthritis, which is a degenerative joint disease characterized by joint pain, stiffness, decreased range of motion, and the presence of osteophytes (bony outgrowths) visible on x-ray. The patient's history of repetitive hand use as a typist for many years is a risk factor for developing osteoarthritis in the hand joints.

Question: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Prediction:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical presentation and direct immunofluorescence findings is:

C. Bullous pemphigoid

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense, non-rasping blisters that often occur on the trunk, flexural areas, and extremities. It is more common in the elderly and can be associated with new medications. The direct immunofluorescence showing linear C3 and IgG deposits along the basement membrane is a hallmark of bullous pemphigoid.

Question: A previously healthy 18-year-old army recruit is brought to a military treatment facility because of a 3-week history of right foot pain. He recently started basic infantry training and has been running several kilometers daily. Initially, the pain only occurred while running, but now it is also present at rest. The pain is located diffusely over the right forefoot. Vital signs are within normal range. Examination shows mild swelling over the distal right forefoot. Pressing the metatarsal of the third right toe results in pain. He walks with an antalgic gait. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right foot shows a slight loss of cortical density and callus formation at the third metatarsal shaft. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prediction:
The most appropriate next step in management for this patient with a suspected stress fracture of the third metatarsal is:

A. Rest and acetaminophen

Rest and analgesics such as acetaminophen are the initial treatments for a stress fracture. The patient should avoid activities that exacerbate the pain and may need to use crutches to prevent weight-bearing on the affected foot. Further imaging can be considered if the diagnosis is unclear or if there is no improvement with conservative management. However, based on the provided information and the clinical presentation, immediate additional imaging is not necessary. Rest and pain management are the priority to prevent further injury.

Question: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed the bluish lip discoloration worsen when she fed and improve when she cried. The patient's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. The crying infant's lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
Prediction:
The symptoms and signs described in the question suggest that the newborn might be suffering from a congenital heart defect, specifically a cyanotic heart defect, given the bluish discoloration of her lips (cyanosis) and the worsening of the cyanosis during feeding. The improvement of cyanosis when the baby cries could be due to the increased blood flow and oxygenation that crying induces. The heart rate and blood pressure are also indicative of a newborn in distress.

Option B, a boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray, is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect that can present with cyanosis and respiratory distress. TOF consists of four defects: a ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. The "boot-shaped" or "coeur en sabot" appearance on chest x-ray is due to the enlargement of the right ventricle and the narrowing of the pulmonary artery, which gives the heart a distinctive shape.

The other options do not fit the clinical presentation as well:

A. Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray could indicate a lung disease or infection, but this is not the most likely diagnosis given the presence of cyanosis and the improvement with crying, which are more indicative of a cardiac issue.

C. Passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth not possible would suggest an esophageal atresia or other obstruction in the upper digestive tract, which does not explain the respiratory distress and cyanosis.

D. Passage of a catheter through the nasal cavity not possible could indicate a nasal obstruction, which would not explain the respiratory distress and cyanosis.

E. Scaphoid abdomen refers to an inward curvature of the abdomen, which is not related to the symptoms described and does not explain the respiratory distress and cyanosis.

Therefore, the most likely answer is:

B. Boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray, indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot or another cyanotic heart defect.

Question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother 30 minutes after the sudden onset of shortness of breath, dizziness, abdominal pain, and urticaria. The symptoms began 5 minutes after she ate a peanut butter sandwich. Her respirations are 36/min and blood pressure is 84/50 mm Hg. There is stridor on auscultation of the chest. She is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and the appropriate pharmacotherapy are begun. The drug administered to this patient most likely has which of the following effects on cardiac pacemaker cells during an action potential?
Prediction:
The drug administered to this patient in the context of anaphylaxis and hypotension is most likely epinephrine. Epinephrine has several effects on the heart, including increased heart rate and contractility. These effects are mediated by increased Ca2+ influx during phase 0 of the action potential, which is not one of the options provided. However, the closest option to this effect is:

A. Increased Ca2+ influx in phase 4

However, it should be noted that phase 4 is the resting phase where the cell membrane returns to its resting potential, and Ca2+ influx is more prominent during phase 0, which is the rapid depolarization phase. Since none of the options directly describe the effect of epinephrine on phase 0, option A is the most appropriate choice given the provided options, as it suggests an increase in Ca2+ influx, which is associated with increased cardiac contractility and pacemaker activity.

Question: A 3-day-old boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for seizures. He was born to a 33-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation via cesarean section. His birth weight was 1400 grams. Vital signs are significant for systemic hypotension, bradycardia, and hypoventilation. On physical exam, the patient has an altered level of consciousness with decreased spontaneous and elicited movements. The patient is hypotonic on motor testing, has bulging anterior fontanelle, and appears cyanotic. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
Prediction: The best next step in management for this patient is B. Cranial ultrasonography. Given the patient's prematurity, hypotonia, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered level of consciousness, there is a high suspicion for intracranial pathology, such as intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), which is common in preterm infants. Cranial ultrasonography is a non-invasive, bedside imaging modality that can quickly assess for IVH and guide further management. While the other options may be indicated at some point, cranial ultrasonography is the most urgent and appropriate initial imaging study in this scenario.

Question: A 39-year-old man seeks an evaluation in the emergency room due to an episode of syncope at work. He says that he has felt increasing shortness of breath while exercising over the past 6 months. He is a well-built man in mild distress. The vital signs include heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure 135/90 mm Hg. The cardiac examination is significant for a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left lower sternal border which is accentuated by forceful expiration against a closed airway. Palpation of the carotid artery shows 2 closely spaced pulses which occur during systole. Which of the following is most consistent with these findings?
Prediction: The clinical presentation and physical examination findings are most consistent with option B, aortic stenosis. The patient's symptoms of syncope and increasing shortness of breath during exercise, along with the physical examination findings of a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left lower sternal border and a double carotid upstroke (known as a "water-hammer" or "Corrigan's pulse"), suggest aortic stenosis. The murmur is accentuated by forceful expiration against a closed airway, which is a maneuver that increases left ventricular contractility and accentuates the murmur in aortic stenosis. The double carotid upstroke is due to the aortic valve opening and closing rapidly, creating two systolic peaks. This is often seen in severe aortic stenosis.

Question:
A 26-year-old nullipara presents to her physician for a routine check-up at 18 weeks gestation. She has no co-morbidities. Her only complaints are fatigability and a depressed mood for the past 2 weeks. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure, 125/80 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; respiratory rate, 14/min; and temperature, 36.7℃ (98℉). The physical examination is unremarkable and the gynecologic examination is consistent with 18 weeks gestation. A thyroid profile s ordered to check for a possible cause of the fatigability and decreased mood:
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) 0.3 mU/L
Total T4 160 nmol/L
Free T4 13 pmol/L
Corresponding to the obtained results, how should the patient be managed?
Prediction:
The patient's thyroid function tests indicate a low TSH level (0.3 mU/L) and a normal total T4 (160 nmol/L) and free T4 (13 pmol/L). A low TSH with a normal free T4 suggests subclinical hyperthyroidism. In pregnancy, the thyroid undergoes physiological changes to meet the increased metabolic demands, which can sometimes mimic hyperthyroidism. However, since the patient is symptomatic with fatigue and depression, it is important to rule out other causes and ensure that her thyroid status is not contributing to her symptoms.

Option D, prescribing methimazole, is used to treat hyperthyroidism, but it is not typically the first-line treatment in pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus. Levothyroxine (Option A) is used to treat hypothyroidism and would not be appropriate in this case.

Given the patient's symptoms and the possibility of subclinical hyperthyroidism, the best initial step would be to further investigate the cause of her symptoms. Option C, recommending an additional anti-TPO (thyroid peroxidase) test, can help determine if there is an autoimmune component to her thyroid condition. Anti-TPO antibodies can be present in conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis or Graves' disease, which could explain her symptoms.

Option E, recommending an additional T3 assessment, could also be considered if there is a suspicion of T3 toxicosis, which is a less common form of hyperthyroidism. However, since the patient's symptoms are more aligned with fatigue and depression, which are not typically associated with hyperthyroidism, this might not be the first test to order.

Considering the options, the most appropriate initial management would be Option C, to recommend an additional anti-TPO test, to further evaluate the thyroid condition and determine if there is an autoimmune etiology contributing to her symptoms. If the anti-TPO test is positive, further management would depend on the results and the patient's clinical status. If the anti-TPO test is negative and there are no other clear causes for her symptoms, closer monitoring and possibly a referral to a mental health professional for her depressed mood could be considered.

Question: A 42-year-old man presents to your office complaining of right-sided facial swelling that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to India. On examination, the patient has an obvious distortion of the facial features on the right without erythema or lymphadenopathy. A neurological exam reveals no deficits. His blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 65/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F). The patient states that he has been having trouble chewing his food, but is not experiencing any pain. The patient is up to date on all of his immunizations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his facial swelling?
Prediction: Based on the information provided, the most likely cause of the patient's facial swelling is Option B: a benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue. This type of tumor, often referred to as a pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common type of salivary gland tumor and typically presents as a slow-growing, painless mass. The patient's lack of lymphadenopathy, erythema, and neurological deficits, as well as the absence of pain, are consistent with a benign process. The difficulty in chewing without pain also suggests a mass in the salivary gland rather than an acute infection or inflammation.

Question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. His mother reports multiple instances over the past month when she walked into his room while he was masturbating. She is worried he may be going through some sort of “problem.” He is currently in 9th grade; his mother says that he is the captain of his high school wrestling team and does reasonably well in school. On examination, he seems embarrassed and avoids making eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prediction: The most appropriate next step in management would be to reassure the mother. Masturbation is a normal and healthy part of sexual development and exploration, particularly during adolescence. It is important to provide the patient and his mother with accurate information about sexual health and development, and to address any concerns or misconceptions they may have. There is no need for medical intervention or therapy in this case, as the behavior is not indicative of a problem or disorder. Options A, B, C, and E are not appropriate in this situation.

Question: A 64-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatigability and breathlessness when climbing stairs for the last 2 weeks. He also mentions that he occasionally has bouts of cough at night after about 2–3 hours of sleep which is relieved when he sits upright. He denies shortness of breath at rest, palpitations, and loss of consciousness. He has had hypertension for the last 20 years and is on antihypertensive medications. On physical examination, his temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg, and respirations are 18/min. Chest auscultation reveals crackles over the lung bases bilaterally. Examination of his abdomen reveals mildly tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigation results include a hemoglobin of 14.8 g/dL (9.18 mmol/L) and an elevated serum B-type natriuretic peptide. His two-dimensional echocardiogram reveals an enlarged left atrium and an ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following novel drugs is most likely to benefit the patient in addition to valsartan?
Prediction:
The patient's symptoms and examination findings are suggestive of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The presence of nocturnal cough, bilateral lung crackles, and hepatomegaly, along with the elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level, point towards this diagnosis. Among the options provided, sacubitril (option D) is the most likely to benefit the patient in addition to valsartan.

Sacubitril is a prodrug of the neprilysin inhibitor sacubitril, which is combined with the angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) valsartan in a single pill (sacubitril/valsartan). This combination is approved for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), but it may also have benefits in patients with HFpEF. Neprilysin is an enzyme that breaks down natriuretic peptides, and sacubitril inhibits this enzyme, leading to increased levels of natriuretic peptides, which have vasodilatory and natriuretic effects. This can help reduce the workload on the heart and improve symptoms in heart failure patients.

The other options are not as relevant to the patient's condition:
A. Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor used for the treatment of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis.
B. Ivabradine is a heart rate-lowering medication used for the treatment of stable angina and chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
C. Moxonidine is an alpha-2 agonist used for the treatment of hypertension.
E. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor used for the treatment of hypertension.

Therefore, the correct answer is D. Sacubitril.

Question: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that he recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. When the patient retired, his goal was to finally be able to go out with his wife; however, he finds that he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. His inability to stay awake has been straining his marriage as his wife is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help. The patient’s wife claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states he feels rested when he awakes. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Prediction: The most likely diagnosis for the patient is C. Advanced sleep phase disorder. This is characterized by an internal body clock that is set earlier than the typical 24-hour cycle, causing the person to feel sleepy much earlier in the evening and wake up earlier in the morning than most people. The patient's symptoms of feeling rested when he awakes and being unable to stay awake past 6 pm, despite his efforts to stay awake with caffeine, are consistent with this disorder. The fact that his neurological exam is within normal limits and that he has no other medical conditions that could be causing his sleep issues also supports this diagnosis.

Question: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against influenza. Her last mammography 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Two years ago, a pap smear and colonoscopy were normal. She has a history of hypertension. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 years. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years. She drinks 4–5 glasses of wine per day. She goes ballroom dancing twice each week. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prediction:
The most appropriate next step in management for this 62-year-old woman would be:

B. Dual-energy x-ray bone absorptiometry

Given her age and history of smoking and alcohol consumption, she is at risk for osteoporosis. The bone density scan (DXA or DEXA scan) would be appropriate to assess her bone density and determine if she has osteoporosis or osteopenia, which could guide further management such as lifestyle modifications or pharmacological treatment.

While some of the other options may be indicated under different circumstances, they are not the most appropriate next step based on the information provided:

A. Pap smear - She had a normal pap smear two years ago, and typically, pap smears are repeated every 3-5 years if previous results have been normal.

C. Abdominal ultrasonography - There is no indication for this based on the information provided.

D. Low-dose chest CT - This is not typically indicated for routine screening in an asymptomatic patient without a significant history of lung disease or exposure.

E. Transesophageal echocardiography - This is a more invasive test typically used to evaluate specific cardiac conditions and is not indicated for routine screening in an asymptomatic patient. The soft S4 gallop noted on examination may be related to her hypertension and age, but further evaluation with a transthoracic echocardiogram might be more appropriate initially if there are concerns about cardiac function.

Question:
A 25-year-old female with Hodgkin's lymphoma presents with a several day history of edema. Lab studies show:

Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L
Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L
Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL
Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL
Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL

Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Prediction: The most likely diagnosis in this case is B. Membranous nephropathy. This is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and can be associated with malignancies such as Hodgkin's lymphoma. The presence of 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts in the urinalysis, along with low serum albumin (hypoalbuminemia), are indicative of nephrotic syndrome, which is often seen in membranous nephropathy. The edema that the patient is experiencing is also a typical symptom of nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of albumin and subsequent decrease in oncotic pressure.

Question: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of mild left-sided abdominal pain when lifting heavy objects that has developed over the past 6 months. He has had a weight loss of 41 kgs (90 lbs) in the past year. Physical examination shows a soft bulge inferior and lateral to the navel on the left. A CT scan of the abdomen of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following muscles is located directly medial to the pathology seen on the CT scan?
Prediction: The CT scan shows a hernia, which is a bulge in the abdominal wall. The location of the hernia is inferior and lateral to the navel on the left, which is consistent with a left inguinal hernia. The muscles that are directly medial to the inguinal hernia are the rectus abdominis muscles. Therefore, the correct answer is D. Rectus abdominis.

Question: A 7-year-old woman presents shortly after her birthday with red scaly plaques over both ears. Her mother reports that the patient recently received a pair of fashionable silver earrings from her older sister as a birthday present. Physical examination is only significant for erythema and tenderness over the lobules of the ears bilaterally. Her vital signs show a blood pressure of 121/73 mm Hg, heart rate of 72/min, and a respiratory rate of 21/min. Her medical history is non-significant. Of the following options, which is the mechanism of this reaction?
Prediction: The mechanism of this reaction is D. Type IV–cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction. This type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T-lymphocytes and is typically seen in conditions such as contact dermatitis, which is consistent with the patient's presentation of red scaly plaques on her ears after wearing new earrings. This reaction usually occurs 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen, in this case, the metal in the earrings.

Question: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has bowel movements 10–12 times daily; the stool contains blood and mucus. He constantly has the urge to defecate. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the abdomen shows diffuse tenderness to palpation. Serum concentration of C-reactive protein is 20 mg/L (N<10). Colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. Which of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
Prediction:
The patient's symptoms and findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that affects the colon and rectum. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and the presence of pseudopolyps and ulcerations in the colon and rectum, as seen in the colonoscopy. The elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level also suggests an inflammatory process.

Among the given options, the greatest risk for a patient with ulcerative colitis is developing colorectal cancer (Option C). Long-standing ulcerative colitis, particularly when it involves the entire colon (pancolitis), increases the risk of colorectal cancer. This risk increases over time, with the risk being higher after 8-10 years of disease. Regular colonoscopies are recommended for patients with ulcerative colitis to monitor for signs of dysplasia or cancer.

Options A, B, D, and E are not directly related to the complications of ulcerative colitis, although some patients may develop extraintestinal manifestations of IBD such as oral ulcers (Option B). Hemolytic uremic syndrome (Option A) is typically associated with certain bacterial infections and is not a common complication of ulcerative colitis. Gastric cancer (Option D) and pancreatic cancer (Option E) are not directly related to ulcerative colitis and are not increased risks in this patient population.

Question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of a headache. The last menstrual period was 4 months ago. She also reports having a mild headache for 1 month. There has been a grape-like mass protruding from her vagina for the last 15 days. On examination, the fundus of the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus and no fetal heart sounds are heard. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 160/100 mm Hg, pulse rate 108/min. On USG examination, no fetal parts are seen. What will be the genotype of the substance which will be aspirated by dilation and evacuation?
Prediction:
The description given in the question suggests a diagnosis of a molar pregnancy, specifically a complete hydatidiform mole. The presence of a grape-like mass protruding from the vagina, the absence of fetal parts on ultrasound, and the enlarged uterus are all indicative of this condition. A complete hydatidiform mole is characterized by an empty gestational sac with no embryo or fetal tissue, and the uterus is often larger than expected for the gestational age due to the mass of the molar tissue.

Complete moles are typically the result of a single sperm fertilizing an empty egg (nulecule ovum), leading to disomy for the paternal genome and a karyotype of 69,XXY, 69,XYY, or rarely 69,XXX, depending on whether the sperm was X-bearing or Y-bearing and whether the duplication was of the X or Y chromosome. However, the most common karyotype in complete moles is 69,XXY.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

A. 69XXY

Question: A 42-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine annual exam. She recently moved from New Jersey, and her medical records show a total colectomy. The patient reports that she has had annual colonoscopies since she was 10 years of age because her father had “a condition with his colon.” What is the genetic inheritance pattern of the patient’s disease?
Prediction: The genetic inheritance pattern of the patient's disease is most likely A. Autosomal dominant. This is because she has a family history of a "condition with his colon" in her father, and she has been undergoing annual colonoscopies since a young age, which suggests a known familial risk. The fact that she has had a total colectomy also indicates a severe colon condition that is often associated with genetic syndromes such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome, both of which are typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Question: A 2-day-old infant male is brought to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of vomiting and irritability. He was born at home and had unreliable prenatal care because his parents have been experiencing housing instability. About a day after birth, he started to become lethargic and was feeding poorly. His parents thought that he might just be tired so they put him to bed; however, by the next morning he started to vomit and act extremely irritable. On presentation, he is found to have nuchal rigidity and bulging fontanelles. Based on this presentation, appropriate cultures are obtained and he is placed on empiric antibiotics. After all cultures grow out the same gram-positive bacteria, the patient is narrowed to penicillin G. Which of the following is a characteristic of the most likely organism that is causing this patient's symptoms?
Prediction:
The patient's presentation, including the nuchal rigidity and bulging fontanelles, suggests a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. The fact that the patient is a newborn and has had unreliable prenatal care further supports this diagnosis, as neonatal meningitis can be caused by various organisms, including group B Streptococcus (GBS), Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes. However, since the patient was narrowed to penicillin G after cultures grew out the same gram-positive bacteria, this suggests that the causative organism is likely sensitive to penicillin G. Among the options given, the characteristic that matches the most likely organism is:

B. Enlarges hemolytic area of Staphylococcus aureus

This characteristic describes the interaction between Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) and Staphylococcus aureus on a blood agar plate, where S. pyogenes can enlarge the hemolytic area of S. aureus due to the production of streptokinase, which activates plasminogen to plasmin, leading to fibrinolysis and an enhanced zone of hemolysis. However, this is not a direct characteristic of the organism causing the infant's symptoms but rather an interaction seen in laboratory settings.

The most likely causative organism in this scenario is Group B Streptococcus (GBS), which is a gram-positive bacterium and a common cause of neonatal meningitis. GBS does not create a green zone of hemolysis on blood agar (A), does not produce lipooligosaccharide (C), does not produce a toxin that increases cAMP levels (D), and does not exhibit tumbling motility in broth at 22 degrees (E). GBS is typically sensitive to penicillin G, which is why the patient was narrowed to this antibiotic after cultures grew out.

Question: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and dyslipidemia comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He says he feels well. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 103 kg (227 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His BMI last year was 27 kg/m2. When asked about his diet, he says, “Being overweight runs in my family. Rather than fight it, I just try to enjoy myself and eat what I want.” Which of the following defense mechanisms best describes the patient's response to the physician?
Prediction: The patient's response to the physician can be best described by the defense mechanism of Rationalization (Option A). Rationalization is a defense mechanism in which the individual justifies their actions or feelings with logical reasons, even if these reasons are not truly valid or relevant. In this case, the patient is rationalizing his unhealthy eating habits and weight gain by attributing them to a genetic predisposition and a desire for personal enjoyment, rather than taking responsibility for his dietary choices.

Question:
A 27-year-old college student presents to his physician for constant fatigue. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some occasional nausea and vomiting which has caused him to lose weight. The patient is a first year college student, drinks alcohol regularly, smokes marijuana, and has unprotected sex with multiple partners. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dL
AST: 85 U/L
ALT: 92 U/L

Urine
Color: Amber/brown
Marijuana: Positive
Amphetamines: Positive
Cocaine: Positive

The patient refuses an examination of his genitals. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?
Prediction:
